How this Page is Made

I use Goodreads to keep track of books I've read but their API is not stellar and they can't provide links to cover images which is a must-have for a shelf view. Since I don't read at breakneck speeds I just made a spreadsheet myself with information from my Goodreads data and links to cover art.

That spreadsheet is turned into JSON with my tool that does the spreadsheet-to-JSON conversion for you. This site is built with Eleventy so I created a template in the HTML that uses that JSON data. You can go directly the template and see the code on Glitch.

Here are the steps to updating this page after finishing a book:

  1. Add a row to my spreadsheet for the finished book.
  2. Generate JSON for the updated spreadsheet with https://spreadsheet.glitch.me/?key=SPREADSHEETKEYHERE.
  3. Copy and paste the updated JSON into the file books.json, see the file in Glitch.
  4. Use Git to commit the changes and push them to Glitch, or do it directly in Glitch with automatic deploys.

There's a duplicate copy of this site's code on GitHub.

entry.title: 2019 Books
entry.content:
I set a goal of reading 12 books in 2019 and I read 19—how about that! There's a shelf view, then some ramblings on what I liked, then a list view and lastly, a how-to, if you want to make a book page, too.

2019 Shelf

Some Highlights

I read more Fiction than I have in many years combined! I enjoyed it, too. I really liked Sally Rooney's Normal People; I was sucked into the world she built and learned some handy Irish slang. Fleishman Is in Trouble, ruined me emotionally for two days (worth it).

Despite venturing away from Non-Fiction more often this year I still enjoyed some great tales of history: The Professor and the Madman is the story of how the Oxford English Dictionary came to be and goes places you wouldn't expect; King Cnut and the Viking Conquest of England is about Cnut, the first Danish King of England, and with this book I started the year true to my love for all this story touches (Denmark! Vikings! Medieval England!); the last book I read this year, The Library Book, tells the story of 1986 fire to the Los Angeles Public Library, the investigation, the restoration and the incredible and inner workings of a library.

I loved The Art Detective because I love the BBC show Fake or Fortune and this book, by one of the hosts, Philip Mould, is the same sort of detective, restoration, and history tales as the show—which, tragically, I wasn't able to find the latest season of unofficially on YouTube this year.

I read my first Science Fiction books this year! Exhalation was beautiful and thought provoking. Ancillary Justice created an atmosphere that spilled into real life and merged with the music I was listening to on my commutes at the time.

I re-read The Course of Love by School of Life's Alain de Botton. And I'd read it again! It uses the story of a fictional couple's marriage over the years to talk about the psychology of relationships and ourselves. Love is a service. I read a few more books from the School of Life, too. And I'll read more!

2019 List
No.TitleAuthorReadCategoryPages
The Library BookOrlean, Susan12/31/2019Non Fiction History317
Exhalation Chiang, Ted 12/29/2019Fiction Science Fiction352
The Art DetectiveMould, Philip 12/20/2019Non Fiction Art274

entry.title: Old English, Old Norse, and Danish!
entry.content:
I originally posted this elsewhere 2018-11-20 but ported it here to have a sample post in order to design this blog.

I love learning about the history of English, especially Old English. A while ago I read Stories of English and loved it so much that I have moved with it for a decade, across the Atlantic and twice across the US.

Last year I started learning Danish (with the help of Duolingo and Danish friends) and it re-ignited my interest in Old English. So I've read more and am 100+ hours into The History of English podcast, which is incredible. The podcast is so throughly researched and presented!

Unexpectedly, Danish has come to make a lot more sense! Instead of thinking of it as learning a new word for everything there are now many words for which a pattern can be applied to transform it into a modern English word or the Danish word is the same or nearly so as a now lost Old English word.

  • 'sk' pairs in Old Norse became 'sh' in English so skip became ship (b's often became p's) and vask became wash (v's often became w's, think about wine and vin)
  • Old English's fugol for bird and fugl in Danish; Old English's hus for house is still hus in Danish.

I love learning these patterns and the history behind all the changes in the language (though I do wish English had remained more Nordic/Germanic). And I love to share random etymology facts!

Here are some resources:

  • Stories of English, David Crystal
  • Our Magnificent Bastard Tongue, John McWhorter
  • History of English Podcast
  • Great Vowel Shift
  • Grimm's Law

entry.title: What This Is?
entry.content:
Great question. Monica and I made a site that uses Glitch collections to make a new-age webring. It's a static site built with Eleventy. You can remix it on Glitch to create your own site and webring of pals (or whatever).

I've gone and done that myself and now I've got this second (first) site that I'm gonna tinker with, for fun!
